Title: Is it possible to interchange order of supremum and supremum?
Content:
Prove that if A and B are arbitrary sets and f is a bounded real-valued
function on $A\times B$ , then $$ \sup_{a \in A} \sup_{b \in B} f(a,b) = \sup_{b \in B} \sup_{a \in A} f(a,b) . $$ If it is possible, then does it change into one supremum like $\sup f(a,b)$ ? Thanks for help!
AcceptedAnswer:
Assuming  $A
e \phi
e B.$ $$	ext {Let }\;  M=\sup \{f(a,b): a\in A\land b\in B\}.$$ $$	ext {Let }\; M^*=\sup_{a\in A} \sup_{b\in B}f(a,b).$$ $$	ext {For } a\in A \;	ext {let }\; G(a)=\sup_{b\in B}f(a,b).$$ (1) For  $M<\infty$: For $n\in N$ let $$A(n)=\{a\in A:\exists b\in B\;(f(a,b)>M-1/n)\}.$$      We have $ orall a\in A\;(G(a)\leq M).$  So $M^*=\sup_{a\in A} G(a)\leq M.$ And  $ orall n\in N\;( A(n)
e \phi)$, so $ orall n\in N\;(M^*\geq \sup_{a\in A(n)}G(a)>M-1/n).$  Therefore $$ orall n\in N\;(M-1/n< M^*\leq M)$$ which implies $M^*=M.$ (2) For  $M=\infty$: For $n\in N$ let $$A^*(n)=\{a\in A:\exists b\in B\;(f(a,b)>n)\}.$$ Then $ orall n\in N\;(A^*(n)
e \phi)$ , so $$ orall n\in N\; (M^*\geq \sup_{a\in A^*(n)}G(a)>n) 	ext {...... implying } M^*=\infty =M.$$
llm_answer_create_structured_problem:
###BEGIN_OF_FORMAT###
Assumption: 
A is a set,
B is a set,
$f$ is a real-valued function on $A \times B$,
$f$ is bounded.
Problem:
Prove that $$ \sup_{a \in A} \sup_{b \in B} f(a,b) = \sup_{b \in B} \sup_{a \in A} f(a,b) $$ and determine whether this expression can be simplified to $\sup_{(a,b) \in A \times B} f(a,b)$.
###
